text: why do you think the brain is not a computer, what does that mean to you?

> the brain isn't a computer

why?
the last sentence is a terrible way to reason though. you haven‚Äôt described anything about the nature of the human brain, only about the nature of Chatbots (invented 2 years ago)
of course! but we don‚Äôt learn to reason primarily through operant conditioning
the brain is computational substrate, whether it has sticks of dram seems totally irrelevant. the kinds of programs it runs may be significantly different from ChatGPT but that‚Äôs a different story
sure you can. it‚Äôs obvious that LMs develop internal critics as you can see when they backtrack within a rollout, not to mention explicit reward modeling

due to Baldwin effect, learning these things becomes easier over generations. there is not a strict dichotomy between learning and evolution. evolution creates a brain map that makes it easy to recapitulate the learnings of ancestors

hmm don‚Äôt u think this happens all the time anyways due to radiant events, companies failing, people getting sick or quitting 

even things like ‚Äúchinese trade‚Äù get dropoutted by covid
I don‚Äôt work on it. I also think there‚Äôs nothing wrong with working on video modeling

it‚Äôs practically hopeless to estimate the impact of some new technology a priori. literal nuclear weapons led to a hundred years of relative peace. and I certainly don‚Äôt think anyone has a handle on what ai video models will do to the culture

metaphysically, this is important. the brain isn‚Äôt magic, it uses spike train potentials to construct larger abstractions and circuits. it inherits the computationally capacity of physics, it takes inputs, makes outputs. 

it‚Äôs even auto-regressive in time (each mental state depends on the previous time step)
your neural circuitry from birth is optimally compressed via the genome to recapitulate these things. there is much computation involved in the construction that can‚Äôt be taken for granted

people forget about the Baldwin effect when reasoning about the difference between evolution and learning

when you recapitulate learning that your ancestors did, when you learn to see, walk, and speak in an unbroken line for thousands of generations, it gets easier each time
the movement of phosphorus ions is meaningless to you

yes, humans utilize reinforcement learning and operant conditioning to learn motor control. but I don‚Äôt think it‚Äôs how we pick up reasoning! we don‚Äôt do thousands of failed reasoning traces for math problems

everyone is profoundly strange. you probably think you have a strange dysfunctional family but it‚Äôs probably middle of the pack. even the people that are at the median of every distribution are wacky
-Peter Thiel, 2014
this perhaps explains some of the slop feeling of machine intelligence, which sample the space far closer to the centroid than any humans can find
it is difficult for a complex system to fail completely. therefore most of life is described by sub-catastrophic failure modes
